title: Regenerative Agriculture: A Solution to Climate Change

tasks.task: Understand the principles of regenerative agriculture and its impact on soil health and emissions.
subtasks: Comprehend the concept that traditional agriculture negatively contributes to emissions.
Learn that regenerative agriculture practices can offset all emissions faster than soil formation.
Grasp the potential for immediate drawdown effects with regenerative agriculture.
Recognize the trade-offs between regenerative agriculture and chemical-based productivity.

tasks.task: Analyze the labor requirements for transitioning to regenerative agriculture.
subtasks: Acknowledge the current percentage of individuals directly engaged in farming in the US (1%).
Project the increase in the percentage of the population involved in farming to 10%.
Consider the potential even higher involvement (50%) if including gardens.
Understand the necessity of increased labor due to the labor-intensive nature of regenerative practices.

tasks.task: Evaluate the relationship needed between human and land in regenerative agriculture.
subtasks: Recognize the need for patient and attentive observation of land.
Contrast this requirement with the industrial model's standardization.
Understand how the regenerative approach necessitates moving away from industrial thinking.
